chargeHist.descr: Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent

result.execSummary:
The defendant Jesse James Scribner was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.23(2).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Polk County Clerk of Circuit Court

miscConds.notes: $290.60 fine/costs to be paid to Probation while on Probation.

$2,803.38 Restitution, plus 10% surcharge of $280.34, for a total of $3,083.72, to be paid to Probation while on Probation in a payment plan of $50.00 per month beginning 03/01/2017 and due on the first day of each month thereafter.
$250.00 DNA surcharge to be paid to Probation while on Probation.

Must complete HSED or GED during first year of Probation.
Must work up to the level recommended by Mental Health evaluation.
May not possess or use firearms or body armor.
Must undergo a Mental Health evaluation & comply with recommendations.

Not to have contact with Gregory Meyer.  
May not vote or hold public office until civil rights are restored.  
If not a U.S. Citizen, may face deportation or loss of other citizenship rights.
Must write apology letter to victims through Probation.
Eligible for expungment upon successful completion of Probation.

timeConds.notes:
60 days to be served up front.
210 days banked/stayed for use by Probation if necessary.

supervisions.notes:
Subject to Good Time & Work Release.
Consecutive to: 16CF308 - Count 4

Any outstanding financial obligation still due and owing will be reduced to a civil judgment and payable at the Clerk of Court's Office.
May not vote or hold public office until civil rights are restored.  Other civil rights may be lost until restored.  
If not a U.S. citizen, may face deportation or loss of other citizenship rights.
May not possess or use firearms and, if considered a violent felony, no body armor.
